Award.AwardTitle: RCN SEABCRU: The Southeast Asian Bat Conservation Research Unit
Award.AbstractNarration:
Southeast Asia is one of the most biologically diverse regions in the world, and supports about 30% of the world's bat fauna. Bats perform critical ecosystem services as seed dispersers, pollinators and agents of pest control, but rapid land-use change and unregulated hunting imperil many of the region's species. Only 18% are considered to have stable populations and > 20% of species are likely to be globally extinct by the end of this century. Moreover, bats are the natural reservoirs of numerous viruses, but there is growing consensus that it is human-induced environmental disturbances that precipitate the emergence of infectious diseases. Accurate documentation of the distribution, diversity and abundance of bat species in Southeast Asia and the responses of bats to anthropogenic activities is thus urgently needed. The goal of the South East Asian Bat Conservation Research Unit (SEABCRU) RCN is to create a network of international researchers to collate and generate these data through the implementation of research activities centered on four priority areas identified by consensus at a forum in 2007: flying fox distributions and population ecology; taxonomy and systematics; cave bat diversity and conservation; and response of forest-dependent bats to landscape change. The network will develop standardized research protocols for each priority and train Southeast Asian bat researchers in the protocols through a series of workshops. An online community of practice will be established to facilitate and promote communication among researchers to collate, synthesize, and share resulting data, and to promote effective international communication and stimulate collaboration.

The SEABCRU RCN will bring together researchers from across SE Asia, the US and UK with university, museum and NGO affiliations. The research priorities will be supported by student teams that include those from 2-year colleges, four-year colleges, and graduate institutions, and combine US and SE Asian students. The project will generate unique datasets on the diversity, distribution, abundance and systematics of Southeast Asian bats critical for conservation intervention and that can greatly advance our understanding of biogeographic process, community ecology, and the ecological stressors that promote the emergence of infectious diseases in bats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The bats of Southeast Asia, numbering close to 400 species, make up a third of the world's bat diversity and play critical roles in natural and agricultural systems as pollinators, seed dispersers and through consumption of insect pests. Unfortunately, this extraordinary and important diversity faces a multitude of human threats. Their natural habitats, primarily tropical rain forests, are subject to degradation and conversion to agriculture and non-timber plantations. Many species are intensively, and unsustainably hunted, and important cave roosts are threatened by limestone extraction and human disturbance. Before the award, capacity for research to mitigate these threats was very limited in the region, and the few bat scientists that did exist rarely had opportunities to interact and coordinate research activities. International collaborative efforts are important because countries not only share species but also face largely the same conservation issues.

The Southeast Asian Bat Conservation Research Unit (SEABCRU) was established in 2007 as an informal network of US and Southeast Asian bat researchers committed to bat conservation research. The SEABCRU mission is to provide an organizational framework to network and coordinate bat conservation research, capacity building, and outreach across the region.  In 2011 the SEABCRU received an award from the National Science Foundation's Research Coordination Network (RCN) program to assess the distribution, abundance and status of Southeast Asian bats through the implementation of research and training activities centered on four priority areas: flying fox distributions and population ecology; taxonomy and systematics; cave bat diversity and conservation; response of forest-dependent bats to landscape change.   To accelerate networking and capacity building, the award aimed to recruit students and researchers to the SEABCRU, engage them in the research priorities, promote effective international communication and stimulate collaboration. The award elevated and grew the SEABCRU from a handful of enthusiastic founders to a dynamic regional network that has involved more than 500 researchers in diverse activities and is now lead by a core of early career researchers from Southeast Asia and the US.

 Research and capacity building were accelerated through a series of workshops, an international conference series and meetings of the SEABCRU Steering Committee, held across countries. The first workshop brought together existing experts to reach consensus on research methods and key actions in the priority areas (Thailand 2012). Findings were subsequently disseminated to researchers through training workshops in Cambodia (2013), Myanmar (2014), Vietnam (2014), Malaysia (2015, 2016) and the Philippines (2018).   International conferences were held in Indonesia (2011), Malaysia (2015), and the Philippines (2018), and attendance grew from 80 participants in 2011 to > 250 by 2018, with more than 450 people from > 20 countries attending in total. The SEABCRU RCN Steering Committee (SC) includes c. 30 people drawn from 10 countries and is organized around the research priorities. Established researchers initially lead each priority, supported by 3-4 graduate students from the US and Southeast Asia who attended all meetings. A core outcome of the award is the transition of the students to leadership roles in the SEABCRU, securing sustainability post-award.

 To hold the data gathered by SEABCRU activities, a database for occurrence data (the locality a bat species has been captured) was built and populated with more than 40,000 records. The database was the foundation for one US PhD dissertation and will provide a critical resource for evaluating the distribution of bat diversity across Southeast Asia and modeling diversity under future scenarios (land-use change, climate change). 

  Collaborative research has been greatly accelerated, with SEABCRU steering committee alone publishing > 70 papers. These include descriptions of species new to science, descriptive and economic analyses of the importance of bats as agents of pest suppression and as pollinators, and evaluations of the consequences of land-use change for bat diversity. SC members were also major contributors to the open-access book "Bats of the Anthropocene: Bat conservation in a changing world". As the award progressed, the SC focused on collaborative grants that built on the SEABCRU network, and received funding from the US Fish and Wildlife Service to look at the drivers of hunting of flying foxes in Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, and from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility to integrate the SEABCRU database with a library of bat echolocation calls.  

Bats play key economic and ecological roles in society, both positive and negative. Economic benefits derive from their actions as agents of pest suppression, seed dispersal and pollination, and production of guano. There can be (debated) costs associated with bats from "predation" of fruit crops and the potential for infectious diseases to emerge from bat host reservoirs. Equipping biodiversity scientists in the region to break down and assess these costs and benefits through research on bat population sizes, distributions and ecology will protect bats, the local habitats and economies their ecosystem services support, and human health.
